review.title: Seeking Meaning in a Space Made out of Strokes, Radicals, Characters and Compounds
review.abstract: Chinese characters can be compared to a molecular structure: a character is analogous to a molecule, radicals are like atoms, calligraphic strokes correspond to elementary particles, and when characters form compounds, they are like molecular structures. In chemistry the conjunction of all of these structural levels produces what we perceive as matter. In language, the conjunction of strokes, radicals, characters, and compounds produces meaning. But when does meaning arise? We all know that radicals are, in some sense, the basic semantic components of Chinese script, but what about strokes? Considering the fact that many characters are made by adding individual strokes to (combinations of) radicals, we can legitimately ask the question whether strokes carry meaning, or not. In this talk I will present my project of extending traditional NLP techniques to radicals and strokes, aiming to obtain a deeper understanding of the way ideographic languages model the world.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction: the Chinese Writing System
sections.text: The Chinese script uses characters (hànzì in Chinese, kanji in Japanese and hanja in Korean) that are logographic (i.e. a graph represents a word or a morphem).KangXi, one of the most important Chinese dictionaries, contains more than 47,000 characters, and Unicode v. 6 [15] encodes almost 75,000 of them. Such sets of symbols would require superhuman skills to memorize if there were no internal structure that allows the reader to grasp at least approximately the meaning of the character, which is based on radicals and strokes.

sections.heading: 1.3 Going from strokes to radicals to characters
sections.text: But there are also "phonetic" radicals that purport to have no meaning but indicate pronunciation, and there are also other components in signs that are always derived from graphic elements from the same set of calligraphic strokes. This leads us to the question: "When we move from the stroke to radicals, components and signs, when does meaning arise?" In other words, do certain combinations of strokes, with the exception of bùshôu radicals, carry meaning or do they contribute to conveying meaning?

sections.heading: 1.4 Compound words
sections.text: In terms of meaning, there is another semantic layer in the Chinese writing system, namely that of connections. A connection is a group of usually two (but sometimes more) Chinese characters, in which a new meaning emerges that differs from the sequence of individual meanings. A typical example of this is that there is a connection of "one hundred" and "one hundred" (last name) and means "farmer." Japanese WordNet [6] contains more than 40,000 compound word entries (written as two or more kanji letters).In fact, there are four structural levels of the Chinese writing system: 1. Line; 2. Radical, be it bùshōu, phonetic or just a graphic component; 3. Characters; 4. Composite words.We can compare this layering with matter: strokes can be compared with elementary particles that form atoms (radicals). Atoms combine in different ways to form molecules (signs) and molecules form composite words ().

sections.heading: 2 Our model
sections.text: To study the Chinese writing system, we use the following model: Let K be the set of all Chinese characters encoded in Unicode, and G be a graph with vertices K. Each k-K contains the following information: 1. the main radio bùshűu (information from the Unihan database); 2. characters (information from CDL); 3. one or more meanings in Chinese or Japanese (information from Japanese and Chinese WordNets). Points 1 and 2 are mandatory; point 3 is optional (and depends on the use of a certain character in one of the two languages and on the completeness of the two WordNet databases). In the rest of this section, we describe various marginal schemes that can be added to G, as well as induced weights at edges and vertices.
